title: Port Isaac to Port Gaverne Walk Route

images.title: Chris Downer / Port Isaac: harbour entrance
images.caption: Port Isaac: harbour entrance. A fairly high tide at Port Isaac  as can be seen from the map, the tidal limits are some way apart.

images.title: Pam Brophy / Coastal Path: Port Isaac
images.caption: Coastal Path: Port Isaac. The coastal path as it leads from the bottom of the car park.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Harbour at Port Gaverne
images.caption: Harbour at Port Gaverne. The boats are 'parked' against the wall and taken to sea by the tractor.

images.title: Martin Bodman / St Endellion: fish cellars at Port Gaverne
images.caption: St Endellion: fish cellars at Port Gaverne. One of the surviving courtyards of cellars, now owned by the National Trust. Pilchards were once salted and washed and packed into barrels here for export

images.title: Martin Bodman / St Endellion: entrance to Port Gaverne
images.caption: St Endellion: entrance to Port Gaverne harbour. A small vessel heads for Port Isaac harbour which lies beyond the immediate headland, left. Beyond is Varley Head.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Lane from Port Isaac to Port Gaverne
images.caption: Port Gaverne, at end of lane from Port Isaac. Narrow lane leading down to the village with the harbour inlet on the left.

description: This short walk takes you along a lovely section of the Cornish coast around Port Isaac and Port Gaverne. The walk starts at Port Isaac Harbour where you can pick up the South West Coast Path and follow it east to neighbouring Port Gaverne, passing Castle Rock and Cartway Cove. You can extend the walk by following the Port Isaac Walk to Port Quin.
